items.title: Does dotmap support sets?
items.body: Hi - thanks for the great + useful module - does dotmap support sets?

items.title: Recursion error inspecting DotMap with inspect.unwrap
items.body:
If I try to unwrap an object to class DotMap I get recursion error; we saw this trying to Document our code using Sphinx 3.0.3. Initially, I raised it on Sphinx; but with the feedback I got; it looks like a DotMap issue?

https://github.com/sphinx-doc/sphinx/issues/7764

**To reproduce:**
```python
# dotmap_exporter.py
from dotmap import DotMap

testdotmap = DotMap()
```
and then use this module in python like so
```python
Python 3.6.10 |Anaconda, Inc.| (default, May  8 2020, 02:54:21)
[GCC 7.3.0] on linux
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import inspect
>>> import sys
>>> import dotmap_exporter
>>> sys.setrecursionlimit(50)
>>> inspect.unwrap(dotmap_exporter.testdotmap)
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/home/calebm/.conda/envs/py36/lib/python3.6/inspect.py", line 516, in unwrap
    raise ValueError('wrapper loop when unwrapping {!r}'.format(f))
  File "/home/calebm/upstream/dotmap/dotmap/__init__.py", line 125, in __repr__
    return str(self)
  File "/home/calebm/upstream/dotmap/dotmap/__init__.py", line 119, in __str__
    items.append('{0}={1}'.format(k, repr(v)))
  File "/home/calebm/upstream/dotmap/dotmap/__init__.py", line 125, in __repr__
    return str(self)
  File "/home/calebm/upstream/dotmap/dotmap/__init__.py", line 119, in __str__
    items.append('{0}={1}'.format(k, repr(v)))
  File "/home/calebm/upstream/dotmap/dotmap/__init__.py", line 125, in __repr__
    return str(self)
  File "/home/calebm/upstream/dotmap/dotmap/__init__.py", line 119, in __str__
    items.append('{0}={1}'.format(k, repr(v)))
  File "/home/calebm/upstream/dotmap/dotmap/__init__.py", line 125, in __repr__
    return str(self)
  File "/home/calebm/upstream/dotmap/dotmap/__init__.py", line 119, in __str__
    items.append('{0}={1}'.format(k, repr(v)))
  File "/home/calebm/upstream/dotmap/dotmap/__init__.py", line 125, in __repr__
    return str(self)
  File "/home/calebm/upstream/dotmap/dotmap/__init__.py", line 119, in __str__
    items.append('{0}={1}'.format(k, repr(v)))
RecursionError: maximum recursion depth exceeded
```

items.title: setdefault does return the value

setdefault doesn't return the default value for further editing.
Fixed in #53

items.title: Tests sometimes fail on Python 3.5 (and earlier) due to random dict key ordering
items.body:
I have tested this on Python 3.5.7.

**N.B. Python versions before [Python 3.6](https://docs.python.org/3.6/whatsnew/3.6.html#new-dict-implementation) have random key ordering.**

The `TestRecursive` test in `dotmap/test.py` is failing some of the time.

The test expects a string:
> DotMap(a=5, recursive=DotMap(...))

Approximately 50% of the time the test passes with:
> DotMap(a=5, recursive=DotMap(...))

The other 50% it fails because:
> DotMap(recursive=DotMap(...), a=5)

This strongly suggests random key ordering is causing the failures. A similar issue was fixed in March 2019 by 2e42af8e4b04d33908430620cfbbd099b3922fdb. I have prepared a similar patch that prevents the failures:

```
diff --git a/dotmap/test.py b/dotmap/test.py
index 64cb6a3..9bbda5f 100644
--- a/dotmap/test.py
+++ b/dotmap/test.py
@@ -206,7 +206,9 @@ class TestRecursive(unittest.TestCase):
         m2 = DotMap(d)
         m2_id = id(m2)
         self.assertEqual(id(m2.recursive.recursive.recursive), m2_id)
-        self.assertEqual(str(m2), '''DotMap(a=5, recursive=DotMap(...))''')
+        outStr2 = str(m2)
+        self.assertIn('''a=5''', outStr2)
+        self.assertIn('''recursive=DotMap(...)''', outStr2)
```

_Originally posted by @allsopp in https://github.com/drgrib/dotmap/pull/51#issuecomment-509598051_

items.title: List of DotMaps, Append
items.body:
Not sure if this is a DotMap issue of a cockpit error, but I noticed a problem when appending dotmaps to a list inside a loop.  This code:

```python
import dotmap
mylist=[]
dd = DotMap()
for i in range(10,40,10):
    dd.apple = i+10
    dd.baker = i-10
    mylist.append(dd)
mylist
```
Produces the results below, which are not what I wanted:

```
[DotMap(apple=40, baker=20),
 DotMap(apple=40, baker=20),
 DotMap(apple=40, baker=20)]
```

Playing around some, by trial and error I discovered that moving the DotMap definition inside the loop gives the desired results:

```python
import dotmap
mylist=[]
for i in range(10,40,10):
    dd = DotMap()
    dd.apple = i+10
    dd.baker = i-10
    mylist.append(dd)
mylist
```

```
[DotMap(apple=20, baker=0),
 DotMap(apple=30, baker=10),
 DotMap(apple=40, baker=20)]
```

Is this the expected behavior?

items.title: handle KeyError instead of returning DotMap() object
items.body:
Hi
How can i handle not found key or KeyError, Now its just return `DotMap()` object .

items.title: getattr/setattr doesnt work
items.body:
So far I have to say I love working with DotMap however I run into the issue that getattr and setattr don't work at the way you expect.

Example:
``` python
>>> from dotmap import DotMap
>>> data = DotMap({'Input': {}, 'Expected': {
...     'HttpResponseCode': '201', 'EndState': 'FullyProcessedOk', 'MaximumTimeUntilEndstate': '60'}
... })
>>> getattr(data, "Expected.EndState")
DotMap()
```

Similar with setattr
I suppose this has to do that it doesnt see the dots as a next branch (like on normal objects) but as 1 key
Any chance there is a way to get this working?

items.title: DotMap objects not raising exception when member accessed before assignment
items.body:
Is this the intended behavior? My feeling is that DotMap should raise an exception e.g. AttributeError (or a subclass).

Example running dotmap version 1.2.39.

from dotmap import DotMap
m = DotMap(a=1, b=2)
m.a
Out[35]: 1
m.b
Out[36]: 2
m.c
Out[37]: DotMap(_repr_mimebundle_=DotMap())

items.body:
dotmap (1.2.24): arrow is pointing on the ** part.

  from dotmap import DotMap
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/dotmap/__init__.py", line 528
    print({**d})
            ^
SyntaxError: invalid syntax

items.title: OrderedDict within a list not creating dotmaps within the list
items.body:
```
Python 3.6.5 |Anaconda, Inc.| (default, Mar 29 2018, 13:32:41) [MSC v.1900 64 bit (AMD64)] on win32
from collections import OrderedDict      
from dotmap import DotMap
a = OrderedDict([('a', 1), ('b', 2), ('c', [OrderedDict([('d', 3)])])])
b = DotMap(a)
b
>>> DotMap(a=1, b=2, c=[OrderedDict([('d', 3)])])
```
fix is to change line 33 from 
`if type(i) is dict:`
to 
`if isinstance(i, dict)`

items.title: Converting simple DotMap to dict works, but vice versa not
items.body:
Here is a very simple example of what I mean with the title:

First create a an empty DotMap with an element of itself:
`dm = DotMap()`
`dm.dm = dm`
Which gives `DotMap(dm=DotMap(...))`.

Then convert it to a normal dict will also work:
`d = dm.toDict()`
Which gives `{'dm': {...}}`.

But when trying to convert `d` back to `dm` it gives an exception:
`RecursionError: maximum recursion depth exceeded while calling a Python object`.

Using Python 3.5.6 and dotmap version 1.2.20.
Also have a look to the picture:
![dot_map_resursion_fail](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7109889/45962755-e5ffcb00-c021-11e8-8bae-02d4ca72d4d7.png)

items.title: looks like a bug
items.body:
https://github.com/drgrib/dotmap/blob/2ef3ac9d80eaa157c3cf7901eccc01097de5c23b/dotmap/__init__.py#L76

shouldn't this be `k in {}`?

items.title: Accessing a key that does not exist does not through an error
items.body:
A dictionary throws an exception when a key that does not exist is accessed while DotMap does not.
It ideally should.

```
>>> from dotmap import DotMap
>>> a = { 'x':'one' }
>>> b = DotMap(a)
>>> a['y']
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
KeyError: 'y'
>>> b.y
DotMap()
```

items.title: variable names as keys don't work.
items.body:
Let's say that this works

>> mymap.foo.bar
2

but using a variable for one of those levels doesn't work:
x="foo"
>> mymap.x.bar
DotMap()

items.title: Dictionary extraction such as c = {**a, **b} not functioning properly.
items.body:
The following was tested on Linux Mint 17, Python version `Python 3.6.2 :: Anaconda custom (64-bit)` and dotmap version `sys.version_info(major=3, minor=6, micro=2, releaselevel='final', serial=0)`
1. `(lambda **x:x)(**DotMap(a=1)) ` returns an unexpected empty dictionary `{}`,
2. `{**DotMap(a=1),**DotMap(b=2)}` returns an unexpected empty dictionary `{}`, and
3. `m = DotMap(); m.a = 2; m.b = 3; print('{a} {b}'.format(**m));` fails with `KeyError: 'a'`.

Other functionality is working properly such as:
1.  `DotMap(a=1)['a']` returns an expected `1`, and
2. `DotMap(a=1).a` returns an expected `1`.

items.title: Integer in dictionary key.
items.body:
Hello,

I have the error below with the following code:

```
>>> d = {1: 'a', 2: 'b'}
>>> m = DotMap(d)
>>> print m
DotMap(1='a', 2='b')
>>> m.1 = 'c'
  File "<stdin>", line 1
    m.1 = 'c'
      ^
SyntaxError: invalid syntax
```

We can not use an integer as a dictionary key?

Regards.

items.title: Deepcopy in loop.
items.body:
Hello,
Before starting thank you for this module.
I do not understand why this little piece of code does not return the expected result.

`import copy
from dotmap import DotMap
l = []
d = {'d1': {'d2': ''}}
m = DotMap(d)
for i in range(2):
....      x = copy.deepcopy(m)
....      x.d1.d2 = i
....      l.append(x)

print l
[DotMap(d1=DotMap(d2=1)), DotMap(d1=DotMap(d2=1))]
`

Expected result

`[DotMap(d1=DotMap(d2=0)), DotMap(d1=DotMap(d2=1))]`

Can you help me understand?
Regards.

items.title: Error with copy.deepcopy()
items.body:
Performing a deep copy of a DotMap seems to result in an infinite loop that eventually end with the error:
 ```
RuntimeError: maximum recursion depth exceeded while calling a Python object
```

Here is a code example that cause the crash:
```
import copy
from dotmap import DotMap
t = DotMap()
t.a = 1
t.b = 3
f = copy.deepcopy(t)
print(f)
```

PS: Thank you for this package, it is really great!

items.title: FR: _default parameter
items.body: Be able to pass a default value which would act in the same way as an argument to `collections.defaultdict()`

items.title: Support ** unpacking
items.body:
Is it possible to add support for *\* unpacking?

For example

``` python
def test(**kwargs):
    print(kwargs)

a = {'1':'a', '2':'b'}
b = DotMap(a)
test(**a)
test(**b)
```

This prints:

```
{'1': 'a', '2': 'b'}
{}
```

items.title: DotMap.copy does not return an independent copy of the content
items.body:
Currently copy() returns a reference to self, which means you're not working on an unique instance when working on the instance returned by copy()

```
>>> from dotmap import DotMap
>>> d1 = DotMap({'s': 1})
>>> d2 = d1.copy()
>>> d1.x = 2
>>> d1
DotMap(s=1, x=2)
>>> d2 
DotMap(s=1, x=2)
```

items.title: DotMap fails for recursive structures
items.body:
Setting a child value to the parent DotMap will lead to infinite recursions.
Especially this approach works fine for normal `dict`s.

``` python
> some_dict = dict()
> some_dict['some_dict'] = some_dict
> print(some_dict)
{'some_dict': {...}}
```

``` python
> from dotmap import DotMap
> some_dotmap = DotMap()
> some_dotmap.some_dotmap = some_dotmap
> print(some_dotmap)
> print(some_dotmap.toDict())

…
RecursionError: maximum recursion depth exceeded
```

Best regards, Christian

items.title: auto completion for ipython
.toDict() no longer converting nested DotMap to dict?
items.body:
I've been using DotMap for a while to make life easier. Today I came back to some code I'd let sit for a while and it looks like the new version of DotMap is no longer converting child DotMaps into dicts when the parent's .toDict() is called in arbitrarily-nested DotMaps.  Here's a snippet:

```
>>> conf.dep.toDict()
{'facts': {'replication_groups': [DotMap(name='rg1', members=['vdc1', 'vdc2'], options=DotMap(description='My RG'))],
```

In this snippet, `conf` is a top-level DotMap with child `dep`, who has many other children, some of whom are also DotMaps.

This was working six months ago... and I don't think bitrot could have broke it this bad :crystal_ball: 

Am I doing it wrong or did something undocumented change with DotMap?

items.title: Unexpected behavior of `empty()`
items.body:
If you type these lines into ipython:

``` python
x=DotMap({'a': 'b'})
x.b.empty()  # True
print x.b
x.b.empty() # False
```

Inspecting a value should not change whether or not the field is empty.

items.title: [Suggestion] Add support to avoid creating dynamic child creation
items.body:
Hi folks!

I guess would be nice to have a way to avoid creating dynamic child creation. I know this dynamic child creation is here by design, but sometimes this isn't good (for instance, on tests: I would like to ensure I'm using the proper key names on some context)

Current scenario (Again, I know it's dynamic creating by design):

```
from dotmap import DotMap
>>> d = {'key': 'value'}
>>> dm = DotMap(d)
>>> dm.unexisting.key.i.would.like.to.see.burning
DotMap()
```

My suggestion is to add a way to avoid that, for instance:

```
from dotmap import DotMap
>>> d = {'key': 'value'}
>>> dm = DotMap(d, avoid_dynamic_child_creation=True)  # better name please.  =P
>>> dm.unexisting.key.i.would.like.to.see.burning
KeyError: 'unexisting'
```

Thanks!

items.title: Deal with lists (iterable things) with dictionaries inside
items.body:
Hi there!

Just wanna let you know that it breaks when you have a list of dictionaries.

---

Example:

``` python
from dotmap import DotMap
FATHER = {
    'name': 'Father1',
    'children': [
        {'name': 'Child1'},
        {'name': 'Child2'},
        {'name': 'Child3'},
    ]
}


father = DotMap(FATHER)
print [x.name for x in father.children]
```

---

Expected:

``` python
['Child1', 'Child2', 'Child3']
```

---

Got:

``` python
AttributeError: 'dict' object has no attribute 'name'
```

items.title: If provided with invalid syntax, it inserts __members__ and __methods__ keys in a DotMap
items.body:
Hi,
This utility is very useful and the only thing I am worrying about using this is its robustness in handling corner cases. I encountered one as below:
 f = DotMap()

> > > f.MessageType = 'Message1'
> > > f
> > > DotMap(MessageType='Message1')
> > > f.Header = DotMap('data1=value1')
> > > f
> > > DotMap(MessageType='Message1'), Header=DotMap() - Did not add data1
> > > f.Header.Status = DotMap(Code=200 OK)
> > > SyntaxError: invalid syntax
> > > f.Header.Status = DotMap('Code'='200 OK')
> > > SyntaxError: keyword can't be an expression
> > > f.Header.Status = DotMap('Code=200 OK')
> > > f.Header
> > > DotMap( **members**=DotMap(), **methods**=DotMap(), Status=DotMap())
> > > f.Header.Status
> > > DotMap()
> > > f.Header.Status.Code
> > > DotMap()
> > > f.Header.Status.Code = '200 OK'
> > > f
> > > DotMap(MessageType='Message1', Header=DotMap(**members**=DotMap(), **methods**=DotMap(), Status=DotMap(Code='200 OK')))
> > > f.toDict()
> > > {'Header': {*\* '**methods**': {}, '**members**': {},*\* 'Status': {'Code': '200 OK'}}, 'MessageType': 'Message1'}

I do not want the methods and members keys to be added,

items.title: Add a warning mode
items.body:
Would be nice to have a warning mode when you overwrite a value for a key already defined.

``` python
from dotmap import DotMap
m = DotMap(warning=True)

m.author.reference="123"
m.author.reference="234"
Warning: overwrite author.reference 
```
